bibl.title: Letter from Martha P. Houston to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, January 6, 1902

div1.p: Houston provides news of Mabel Lazear and her children, as well as the effort to secure a pension for her.

div1.head: Letter from Martha P. Houston to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, January 6, 1902
div1.p:
I was so glad to
get your letter, and I fear I have
not been as prompt in writing as
I ought to have been. But I have had
some interuptions. As my son and
family were with me for nearly
two weeks, and have just left for
This Country -- except Fred who is still
here. I moved my desk into the
Baby s room, and whenever I was
ready to write she was always asleep
The little garments for Margaret,
this box for Houston, and the pin
cushion came safely. Mabel was
very much pleased, with them,
This little dresses are lovely for
baby- Mabel wishes me to thank
you very much for them all.
I often think I will at once
jot down Houston s cute sayings,
at once. that I may write them to
you. The other morning as Mabel
changed his night gown” he said
gannie made this blue nighty
for me and when she comes to
my house, I will say “Baltimore
Ganny”. Tonight as he was about
to be put to bed he piled all the
toys he has in his crib till there
was no room left-

Mabel took him up to Anne Fields
to luncheon the other day, and he
had such a fine time that he stand
till five o'clock, this is the first
time he has been out to lunch.
The baby has fourteen teeth all told
now, she does not pretend to creep
now, but walks every where-

I received a letter from Frances
giving me an account of her visit
with Nellie. I was very much
interested in her letter.

Mabel has had a very nice letter
from President Gilman, one from
Dr Hurd, and from Dr Paton.
He wrote this article in the Boston
Transcript was written by President
Elliot. of Harvard, in regard to the
memorial for Jesse. We are so anxious
to see this paper. Dr Paton said he
would send a copy to Mabel-
Jennie first wrote us about it.
She said she felt so interested
she wanted to give all her Christmas
money towards it. But Walter told
her he would gladly contribute for
her- Mabel is still engaged with
writing business letters-

We are certainly having an open
Winter. We have had no rain to speak
of since you left here- And the
farmers are looking anxiously for
rain- I was very much pleased
with this pretty collar Mrs Seth send
me & thought it very sweet of
her to remember me-

Did I write you we have not
seen this Murrays but once since
you went away they called one
evening they wished me to give
their love to you-

It just happens that we have not had
an opportunity to call upon them
much to our regret.

This must be all this time with
love and best wishes to you
my dear friend.
